newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: More voter support for Australian goods tax - poll.
newsitem.headline: More voter support for Australian goods tax - poll.

text.p: The Australian government's push for tax reform received a boost on Wednesday with another poll showing increasing voter support for a consumption tax.
The Sydney Morning Herald poll showed 68 percent of voters supported a conditional 15 percent Goods and Services tax (GST), up from 64 percent in the last poll in June 1996.
This is the second poll this week to show rising support for a GST as the government pushes the tax reform debate and refuses to rule out a GST if it wins a second term.
On Monday, a poll in the Bulletin newsweekly magazine showed support for a GST rising to 59 percent from 56 percent a year ago.
The Herald's poll put opposition to a value-added tax at just 22 percent, down from 27 percent. The Bulletin's poll showed opposition falling to 31 percent from 37 percent.

Prime Minister John Howard and Treasurer Peter Costello have pushed the need for tax reform in recent weeks and have refused to rule out imposing a GST if the Liberal-National government wins a second term in power.

The coalition's plans for a GST are widely blamed for its failure to win the 1993 election. But it ousted the 13-year-old Labor government in 1996 after pledging not to implement a GST in its first three-year term.

The Herald poll found the proportion of voters who strongly supported a 15 percent GST, excluding foodstuffs, increased to 33 percent from 28 percent, while ordinary support slipped to 35 percent from 36 percent.
The number of voters who strongly opposed the tax fell to 10 percent from 14, while ordinary opposition fell to 12 percent from 13 percent.
The Herald poll surveyed 2,065 voters around the country by telephone over the last weekend.
